Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Policy Geography of Environmental Risk

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scholars of U.S. environmental policy have long recognized that subnational institutions can influence policy implementation, but there has been virtually no attention given to the specific role of sub-state pollution control agencies' regional offices in carrying out federal laws. This is a major oversight that may substantially affect our understanding of how political, economic, and administrative factors influence the government's management of environmental risks. In this project, the research team uses a new approach to examine how overlapping administrative, political, and environmental problem boundaries shape the distribution of policy outputs and outcomes. They term this approach policy geography, and argue that it can induce governance challenges in the form of delegation problems, coordination dilemmas, and inequitable policy delivery, each of which has important implications for the management of environmental risks. Using newly-collected, fine-grained institutional data, the team utilizes software ogf geographic informtion systems to map out each of the 50 state's regional office policy geography for implementation of both the Clean Air Act (CAA) and the Clean Water Act (CWA) for 2002-2012. They then combine this information with facility-level data on policy outputs (government inspections and enforcement actions) and policy outcomes (compliance and pollution risks) to test theoretically informed hypotheses on political control, policy coordination, and environmental justice. These tests are conducted using hierarchical linear models to account for the nested structure of the data.

The proposed research will benefit ongoing policy efforts to manage environmental risks. The results of this research will inform our understanding of the origins of environmental risk patterns, and enhance our capacity to evaluate policy prescriptions aimed at mitigating unfavorable or uneven risk levels across society. In this sense, the proposal speaks to the core tenants of NSF's mission to "promote the health, prosperity and welfare of its citizens." The risks presented to the public from pollution remain important and substantial. For example, over 150 million Americans currently live in areas that are not meeting air quality standards for at least one major air pollutan), and more than 40,000 bodies of water are deemed "impaired" for failing to meet their use requirements. The CAA and the CWA are the primary safeguards against risks from air and water pollution, and understanding their implementation is critical to assure the effectiveness and fairness of pollution control across society. By examining the effects of different institutional arrangements on policy outcomes, the research can identify opportunities for re-configurations that will yield improved environmental governance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scholars of U.S. environmental policy have long recognized that subnational institutions can influence policy implementation, but there has been sparse attention given to the specific role of state pollution control agencies? regional offices in carrying out federal laws. This is a major oversight that may substantially affect our understanding of how political, economic, and administrative factors influence the government?s management of environmental risks. To address this gap in the literature, this project has developed a new policy geography approach to examine the effects of overlapping administrative, political, and environmental problem boundaries on environmental policy outputs and outcomes.

The project has resulted in the creation of several new data products. First, the PIs collected fine-grained information about the organizational design of state environmental agencies. These data, collected through the completion of approximately 300 interviews, allows for the measurement of key decision-making points within agencies pertaining to implementation of the federal Clean Air Act (CAA) and Clean Water Act (CWA). More specifically, the data consist of detailed information about where within agencies choices are made on key implementation decisions regarding compliance monitoring and regulatory enforcement.  

A second data product consists of detailed information on the geographic organization of state environmental agencies. Specifically, through documentary research and confirmatory information gathered through interviews, the PIs determined the extent to which state agencies have decentralized policy authority for implementing the CAA and CWA to regional and local offices. The PIs then delineated the specific governance boundaries of these sub-state offices, and created spatial data files using Geographic Information Systems. 

To develop the policy geography framework, the PIs combined the newly-collected administrative data with secondary data on political boundaries (e.g., state legislative districts), environmental resource boundaries (e.g., watersheds), firm-level information on environmental performance (e.g., compliance), government agency policy outcomes (e.g., regulatory enforcement), and other contextual data (e.g., political, economic, and social indicators). The PIs will release all of the data compiled as part of the project for use by other scholars, as well as create an online website interface to make the data easily accessible to practitioners and the public.

The combination of these data, and specifically their integration, enables the PIs to address theoretically important questions about political influences on bureaucratic performance, policy coordination, and the distribution of environmental risks and policy outcomes across time and space. Through statistical analysis of the newly collected and combined data, the PIs have begun to identify the effects of different institutional arrangements on policy outcomes. For example, the PIs have found that the misalignment of state regional office boundaries and environmental resource boundaries creates policy coordination problems for regulatory officials. As another illustration, the PIs have found that decentralization of decision-making within agencies (i.e., moving authority for decisions down the vertical chain of command) tends to increase the allocation of enforcement effort.

These types of findings reveal potential institutional reform paths for environmental agencies that can yield improved environmental governance, thereby generating societal benefits in the form of reduced risks to human health and the environment.
